title: How to Apply Neosporin
category_hierarchy: First Aid and Emergency Health Care

steps.headline: Wash your wound with soap and cool water.
steps.description: Hold your wound under cool running water, or pour cool water overtop your wound. Use antibacterial soap and a clean washcloth to wash the area around your wound. You can also wash your wound with a homemade saline solution. Soap may cause irritation, so be careful as you wash around your wound. You can also clean your wound with alcohol or hydrogen peroxide. Check with your doctor before using these, as they may damage your skin.

steps.headline: Rinse and dry your wound thoroughly.
steps.description: Make sure you rinse away all soap residue. You can either air dry your wound or pat it try with a towel or washcloth. Be gentle, as your wound may be sensitive.

steps.headline: Wash your hands before and after you clean your wound.
steps.description: Using soap and water, clean your hands once your wound is washed. This will prevent the spread of any germs or bacteria. Also dry your hands after they are washed.

steps.headline: Double-check instructions on the label.
steps.description: The Neosporin package will have information for particular cases, like what to do for children or when to see a doctor. Read over the instructions before you apply the Neosporin, so you are caring for your wound properly.

steps.headline: Squeeze a small amount of Neosporin out of the tube.
steps.description: This will depend on the size of your wound, though strive for about the same amount of Neosporin for the size of your wound. You shouldn't need more than about the size of your fingertip. Try to avoid using too much extra Neosporin. Using too much will oversaturate your wound and waste the Neosporin. Avoid touching the tip of the Neosporin tube with your hands, wound, or other surfaces. Put the cap back on the tube of Neosporin as soon as possible.

steps.headline: Use your finger or a cotton swab to apply Neosporin to your wound.
steps.description: Gently rub an even layer over the entire affected area. You only need one thin layer each time you apply it.

steps.headline: Reapply Neosporin 1 to 3 times a day for no more than 7 days in a row.
steps.description: Neosporin is not dangerous, though you don’t want to overdo it. If your wound is not healing after using Neosporin for a week, or if you start to see signs that your wound is infected, see your doctor for other treatment options.

steps.headline: Cover your wound with a bandage after you apply Neosporin.
steps.description: This will protect the affected area from further injury or infection. You can also use sterile gauze and adhesive tape.

steps.headline: Change your bandage 1 time a day to keep your wound clean and dry.
steps.description: Change your bandage at any time of the day that works for you, as long as your wound is freshened up once per day. When you change your bandage, wash your wound and reapply Neosporin to keep your wound moist and clean.

steps.headline: Use larger bandages for serious wounds.
steps.description: Large bandages are better to cover the size of bigger wounds. You can find them in drug stores or most grocery stores. If you aren’t sure of what size bandage to use, ask your doctor.

steps.headline: Throw away expired Neosporin.
steps.description: If you have Neosporin leftover beyond the expiration date, get rid of it. Expired Neosporin will not heal your wounds and may cause further infections.
